header_summary:
Jeremy proposes an innovative security model for vaults that incentivizes the honesty of signing oracles through continuous payment, contrasting with the one-time gain from potential dishonesty. This model employs private key generation and suggests using a 2-of-2 multisignature setup to limit oracles' ability to compromise the system, addressing the challenge of ensuring continuous operation or "liveness" through multiple security mechanisms [source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/30440182-3d70-48c5-a01d-fad3c1e8048en@googlegroups.com/T/#m8423420dacdd1cb73ef8cdf320e3a0351fbd427a).

/dev /fd0 launches an initiative to gather Bitcoin developers' opinions on various covenant proposals, aiming to build consensus for upcoming soft forks through a collaborative approach similar to the SegWit support page. This effort is facilitated by a draft Bitcoin wiki page, which lists relevant opcodes and invites further contributions, emphasizing the importance of developer input in simplifying the process towards the next soft fork [source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/028c0197-5c45-4929-83a9-cfe7c87d17f4n@googlegroups.com/T/#u#m91e5a68b8275a73acdcc8fc2276b9caf678fdab4).

Ethan Heilman delves into the cryptographic principles of proving the equivalence of two variables in a scripting context, highlighting the complexity and nuances in Bitcoin development and cryptographic security. This discussion illustrates the use of OP_DUP operation to demonstrate absolute certainty in script values, underscoring the importance of understanding script operations and transaction semantics [source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAEM=y+W2jyFoJAq9XrE9whQ7EZG4HRST01TucWHJtBhQiRTSNQ@mail.gmail.com/T/#ma6bea9a7a49e563fd36ff17be9adfab7456d314b).

In a collaborative effort, sCrypt and StarkWare demonstrate the feasibility of a bridge covenant on Bitcoin, connecting it to the Starknet Layer 2 network. This proof-of-concept showcases advanced scripting for managing deposit and withdrawal requests efficiently, leveraging a secure Merkle tree structure for transaction integrity and security. The initiative paves the way for further exploration and development in Bitcoin's ecosystem, offering a technical foundation for building bridges and enhancing interoperability with Layer 2 networks [source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/implementing-a-bridge-covenant-on-op-cat-enabled-bitcoin-a-proof-of-concept/1291).

recent_posts.title: Un-FE’d Covenants: Char-ting a new path to Emulated Covenants via BitVM Integrity Checks
recent_posts.summary:

- Oracles are kept unaware of specific transactions to prevent targeted malicious acts.

recent_posts.title: ColliderScript: Covenants in Bitcoin via 160-bit hash collisions
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion illustrates proving y1 and y2 equivalence in scripts, using OP_DUP for (w,t) values.
- Two transactions, Txn1 and Txn2, demonstrate transactional integrity despite different locking scripts.
- It addresses cryptographic security in Bitcoin, emphasizing script operations and transaction semantics.

recent_posts.title: Implementing a Bridge Covenant on OP_CAT-Enabled Bitcoin: A Proof of Concept
recent_posts.summary:
- A demo bridge between Bitcoin and Starknet Layer 2 was developed by sCrypt and StarkWare.
- The bridge efficiently processes deposits and withdrawals through batching in a Merkle tree.
- The project's codebase, including tests, is publicly available on GitHub for developer contribution.

recent_posts.title: Radpool: Decentralised Mining Pool With Futures Contracts For Payouts
recent_posts.summary:
- The text discusses BFT broadcast's advantage in creating consistency without unanimous node agreement.
- It describes the ease of implementing BFT in known membership pools compared to consensus in open systems.
- Radpool's choice of BFT for quick MVP development reflects a preference for efficient solutions.
